{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2994517,"name":"Daniel Wenbo","username":"mendax1234","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mendax1234/{size}/156242_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-19T09:20:39.384Z","cooked":"

If l know my drive motor and turning motor’s gear ratio , and l use Falcon 500 as my drive motor and 775 pro as my turning motor.l also know the diameter of my wheel. How can l calculate the max free speed of my swerve and the max rotational speed of my swerve?

Any answer is appreciated!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2022-01-19T09:20:39.384Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":796,"reads":287,"readers_count":286,"score":4052.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":400741,"topic_slug":"how-to-calculate-the-max-free-speed-of-a-swerve","display_username":"Daniel Wenbo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48748,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-calculate-the-max-free-speed-of-a-swerve/400741/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2994519,"name":"Anand Rajamani","username":"asid61","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/asid61/{size}/7179_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-19T10:01:25.306Z","cooked":"

Max rpm of wheel = Free speed of motor / gear ratio

Gear ratio = driven gear teeth / driving gear terth

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2022-01-19T10:01:25.306Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":15,"reads":284,"readers_count":283,"score":151.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":400741,"topic_slug":"how-to-calculate-the-max-free-speed-of-a-swerve","display_username":"Anand Rajamani","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":21715,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-calculate-the-max-free-speed-of-a-swerve/400741/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2994520,"name":"SndMndBdy","username":"SndMndBdy","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/13edae/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-19T10:27:28.720Z","cooked":"

To answer with particular respect to swerve:

-asid61’s calculation is accurate. To convert this into a linear speed, multiply by the circumference of your wheel. Be mindful of units, because your motor speed will probably be measured in revolutions per minute and your wheel circumference will probably be measure in inches, whereas you may be thinking about robot speed in feet per second. So a full formula would be:

Linear Speed (ft/sec) = motor speed (RPM) / gear ratio * pi * wheel diameter (inches) / 12 / 60

To double check your math, sensible results are in the range of 10-20 feet per second.

You’ll note that this formula is the same for a swerve robot and a west coast drive robot (or pretty much anything other than mechanism). Thats because on a swerve robot, when you are driving without simultaneously rotating, your setup is a lot like those drive trains: All the wheels are pointed the same direction and working together.

-For your wheel rotation speed, (I.e. how fast the wheel can change orientation), the formula is to simply taking the speed of the motor and divide by the gear ratio. Note that the size of the wheel doesn’t matter. Most swerves end up with a final speed here of 50-300 RPM

  • if you were asking about how fast your whole robot can rotate, that’s a bit tricker. As a bit of a simplification, you can do this, assuming your robot is roughly square. First, find the circumference of the circle that is centered in the middle of your robot and runs through your wheel. This will be in the neighborhood of 600 inches, depending on the size and shape of your robot. Now take your linear speed from above (in inches per second) and divide by your circumference (which was inches per robot rotation) and you’ll get your rotational speed in rotations per second.

The intuition behind this formula is that when a swerve is rotating, each of the wheels is pointed so that it is driving along a circle centered around the middle of the robot.

For each of these formulas, bear in mind that these are theoretical top speeds but in practice you’ll get something about 20% slower than this.

SndMndBdy:

wheel diameter (inches)

Can l replace it with the unit meter and get the meter per second unit?

As long as your units are consistent, you should be good. In other words:

Linear Speed (meters /sec) = motor speed (RPM) / gear ratio * pi * wheel diameter (meters) / 60

Wait so how would you calculate the speed your robot is moving? You could theoretically just take the x and y inputs from the controller to find the speed that the robot is moving but when the robot is strafing and rotating at the same time that slows it down.
